title: Will the United States report more deaths attributed to COVID-19 as of 31 December 2021 than will the European Union?
preds: With a difference of 77,284 as of 12/26, it seems very unlikely that the US would back-report that many deaths.

Well, the jump in new US deaths mentioned in my last rationale does seem to have been a reporting artifact. The increase in new cases seems to be more stable.  The EU is still way higher on new cases, which will mean it should remain way higher on new deaths through the end of the year. Given the EU is already higher on total deaths, I do not merely think the probability of a "Yes" is small enough it's worth rounding down to 0, I cannot think of any mechanism that would cause this question to resolve "Yes".

I am assuming that the sudden simultaneous jumps in cases and deaths in the seven-day rolling averages in the US (following the sudden simultaneous declines) is an artifact of reporting around the Thanksgiving holiday. If my assumption is wrong, there is room for a small chance that Omicron is bringing a massive wave of death to the US that will actually change the outcome of this question.

I assume there's a reporting delay in the US this week due to the Thanksgiving holiday, which is why cases and deaths reported have plummeted. But there are presently 65k more cases in the EU than in the US and the gulf is widening each week, a trend unlikely to reverse. If I look back on my specific forecasts from a mid-September when I started following this question closely .... it's an exercise in humility.
I am inclined to go along with @see on this

The EU is so much higher on new cases at the moment that, given the multi-week lag between cases and deaths, it's highly unlikely that the difference in deaths will narrow *any* from the current difference. The odds that the US will exceed the EU death total are utterly negligible.
EU average daily new COVID deaths (per million) continues to surpass that of the U.S. https://ourworldindata.org/covid-deaths?country=~USA~EU
US number is 50% of EU as of now.
53,933 more deaths in EU than US as of 13 Nov and cases in the former are skyrocketing.
Since the last time I looked at this, the EU has greatly risen in daily deaths, now exceeding the United States, which has steadily fallen.

Current trajectory suggests 800k COVID deaths in the US and 900k in the EU. If you look at the per-capita covid fatality map, other than Peru, the most affected countries for the entirety of the pandemic are now in Eastern Europe.
And following the case-rate crossover, the death-rate crossover has now occurred.

Cases in Eastern Europe are jumping up and there are lots of articles about COVID affecting the elderly a lot.  So as cases are increasing, deaths are likely to follow just as winter arrives. Conversely cases and deaths are falling in the US.   So numbers are all going in the wrong direction for this question to resolve yes, and we are too close to the end now for even a sharp reversal to make a difference.

Lowering forecast a bit for now mainly on a slowly rising 7-day rolling average new COVID deaths rate for the EU and a generally falling rate for the U.S. 
Reported difference between the two in cumulative deaths is about +52,400 EU as of 10/31/21: https://ourworldindata.org/covid-deaths?country=~USA~EU

Rapid case growth in Europe all but seals the fate of this question. For accountability: on Sept 20, I predicted that the US and EU would have 730,000 and 778,000 deaths by October 30. The actuals are 745,668	and 797,464, a similar undercount on both tallies. (see https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1335342). Not horrendous. But in the spreadsheet where I'm forecasting trends (not shared publicly), I estimated a 7d rolling average of 700 for the US and 125 for the EU. It's now 1,330 and 1,125. Whoops.

Current trends have brought the totals closer than I'd earlier expected (EU 795K vs US 743K as of 28 October). At the time of my last update in June, it was EU 730K to US 597K. The gap has narrowed massively, and a lot will depend on the next 5-6 weeks as the winter transmission steps up.
Adjusting downward based on case crossover and running out of time in the year.
Looks very unlikely with EU cases and deaths continuing to rise, US deaths now falling as well as cases

Maintaining forecast for now mainly on a slowly declining U.S. COVID deaths forecast over the next few weeks (https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/science/forecasting/forecasting-us.html), and a slowly rising EU rolling 7-day average of daily deaths (https://ourworldindata.org/covid-deaths?country=~USA~EU). The reported cumulative COVID deaths margin has continued to lower to about +54,000 EU as of 10/25/21. This difference was about +79,600 EU a month ago on 9/25/21 (https://ourworldindata.org/covid-deaths?country=~USA~EU). IF this current gap were to continue to narrow at the same rate of about -25,000 per month with about 67 days left until 12/31/21 (from 10/25/21), the ending difference between the two entities could be quite close. The EU's population is generally somewhat more vaccinated than the U.S. (https://www.politico.eu/article/coronavirus-vaccination-europe-live-data-tracker-coverage/), but some eastern European members are lagging significantly (https://www.reuters.com/world/europe/regret-defiance-europes-vaccine-shy-east-covid-19-rages-2021-10-21).

-8. With 67 days left and a difference of a little over 50k cases, the difference between them can't average more than 800 deaths a day or this question will resolve positively. Currently the gap is 585 deaths per day and the EU is trending up while the US is trending down, so this seems fairly unlikely, especially given that US case counts are still declining meaning deaths will trend down for the next 3 weeks at least. Our World in Data: https://ourworldindata.org/explorers/coronavirus-data-explorer?zoomToSelection=true&time=2021-05-19..latest&facet=none&pickerSort=asc&pickerMetric=location&Metric=Confirmed+deaths&Interval=Cumulative&Relative+to+Population=false&Align+outbreaks=false&country=USA~European+Union
Trends suggest there will be more total deaths in the EU than in the US between now and EOY.
Rolling average of EU cases has surpassed US

69 days to go
Deaths at 800 per day in EU, 1500 per day in US
Cumulative US 726k EU 784k: 58k gap
To close gap 58k / 69 = 840.  I.e. US needs 840 more deaths every day than the EU Assume
EU  800 per day more = 55.2k = 840k
US 1500 per day more = 103.5k = 830k It’s close and depends on direction of travel for each region.
Deaths are going up steadily in the EU, but have dipped and plateaued (maybe increasing) in US
Cases are increasing in EU but not US
This pattern makes it less likely the Us will pass the EU.

I think the paths of cases in the US and EU will cross within the week (on 22nd?), and then will likely cross again in December as EU cases subside more quickly. Meanwhile I expect the rates of death will sadly be slightly higher for both than earlier prediction, but as those paths are less likely to intersect the relative difference will be broadly similar to the outcome forecast on 7th October: https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1341488

EU currently has ~60k more deaths and ~800 more deaths per day according to https://ourworldindata.org/covid-cases, which would put the US and EU in a tie for num deaths at the end of the year. But cases in the EU are rising relative to the US, with the 7 day rolling average almost the same and trending toward each other. Cases are a fairly good leading indicator of deaths.

My inside view suggests the numbers will converge, but not cross. The data suggests that crossing is possible. So, I'm reluctantly putting some probability on the possibility. The picture should be clearer with about two weeks more data.
EU deaths and cases both increasing, possibly accelerating; US deaths plateaued and increased slightly and cases still in decline but perhaps hitting a plateau.

September 1st:

- EU: 783

The most surprising thing (to me), and the one making this possibility increasingly and increasingly unlikely, is the slow increase of both cases and deaths in the EU. We've not seen a pattern like this for Covid before, and it may be indicative of a new normal of high vaccination rates and moderate breakout cases and deaths concentrated among the elderly. I'd now rate it at 50% or higher that, at some point before EOY, the 7d rolling average of deaths in the EU surpasses that of the US. Right now I'm forecasting 45k more deaths in EU than USA, an almost 50% increase for that number since I started closely tracking on 20 Sept.

Don’t have time for a full analysis this week but wanted to circle back on my prediction “On 9 Oct: the US will have recorded 710,000 deaths; EU 775,000 (difference of 65,000),” made on 20 September.  Actually are 777,500 and 713,000. Off by 2,500 and 3,000 deaths, respectively, in the same direction.  And yet I’m much less confident now than when I made the prediction. I will be back with add’l forecasts when I get the chance…
I think there's 0% chance, but I suppose I should allow for the possibility.

Daily new confirmed COVID deaths 7-day average has started to decline a bit for U.S. and has slightly increased for the EU as of 10/6/21. Reported gap in cumulative deaths between the two entities is around +67-68,000 EU as of 10/6/21, via this source: https://ourworldindata.org/covid-deaths?country=~USA~EU CDC national forecast for Covid deaths in the U.S. over the next few weeks generally indicates a perceptible decline for the period: https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/science/forecasting/forecasting-us.html
Significant case rates fall in the US requires a drop.

I just don't see this happening. The current gap is around 70k. While many EU countries now have low death rates, four or five in eastern Europe (eg Romania, Bulgaria) have a rising wave of cases which (collectively) contribute around half total EU deaths. These are yet to peak and will prevent any decline EU-wide for at least a few weeks; longer than I had forecast 2-wks ago. Minimum best case scenario now +42k to end of year.  So minimum total deficit 112k. The US conversely would need a worst case to overtake the EU, which would be a reversal of the currently declining wave, and rising cases in to December. This is possible, but even without a booster shot, or continuing mask mandates, I'd still estimate no more than 9M cases or so by year end, and from research on another question https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1337926 that could perhaps lead to 95k further deaths, leaving a minimum of 17k shortfall.
More likely looks like be <8.2M cases, 75-80k deaths, and a deficit approaching 30k+ as we head into December.
Given current death, and vaccine development in both regions, a catch up is unlikely

87 days to do
Assume 1000 on average for the US (assuming rates drop off from 1500 to below 1000 at some point over period) this is 87k extra between now and year end.  US total would be 700k plus 87k = 787k
Assume 750 per day on average for EU (slight increase from now sustained) this is 65k extra. EU total would be 771k plus 65k = 836k For the US to get to 836k it would need 1500 per day.  This is current rates sustained but infections have dropped as have deaths, so this is all likely to continue.In contract EU cases and deaths are increasing slightly. This could be close depending on what happens.  But I’m veering wildly back to no on the basis that the Us is dropping rapidity and the EU is increasing slightly which tips the scales back to no.
Not sure; haven't thought about it yet.

But US cases are dropping so I'm holding at 15 as it seems unlikely US sustains enough to make up the difference. So far things are progressing just about as I forecasted here: https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1335342 And yet at the time I gave a 37% probability, now I am forecasting 22%. What accounts for this? Perhaps:
* I wasn't actually confident in this forecast and I thought the US deaths would accelerate, cases wouldn't taper off.
* Deaths in EU have actually continued to climb, albeit slowly. Cases have also stayed flat and are, of late, climbing again in EU.

The decline in new cases is getting slower in the US, indicating that another wave *might* be imminent. However, that's exactly what seems to be happening in the EU right now, where the Ukraine (which has a full vaccination rate of just 13% in a population of 45M) makes up more than a quarter of deaths. Plus: deaths in the EU have not declined as much as new cases did a few weeks ago. Overall, I believe the US and the EU will suffer badly because neither is close to Delta herd immunity. The EU appears to be a lot closer though with way fewer vaccination gaps so the difference of ~70k deaths might well be closed by 31 December.

Daily new U.S. deaths 7-day average is still almost 4.5 times that of the EU's rate, but may be slightly declining now. The EU has roughly 75,000 more cumulative Covid deaths than the U.S. as of 9/29/21 with about three months to go in the year. (https://ourworldindata.org/covid-deaths?country=~USA~EU). Setting a baseline - 
Currently the EU is at 766,185 and has a death rate of 3725 in the last 7 days [1]
The USA is at 683,243 and has a death rate of 13,831 in the last 7 days At the current rates and using linear projection that means the USA overtakes the EU in 9 weeks or around 1st December.
Obviously linear projection is not accurate in this case but it's a placeholder.
Adding detail the largest population countries in the EU have very high vaccination rates [2] and although there is a current new wave taking place in Romainia it will need to escalate significantly to bring the EU rate above that of the USA, I expect to see stable or declining rates for the EU.
With the USA having somewhat lower rates and entering the autumn / winter season I would not be surprised to see a further increase in death rates from now and I would be surprised to see it decline. So in summary relative to the linear projection I expect that the date where the USA has more deaths than the EU to be earlier than the linear projection of 1st December. More than a week of steadily dropping cases in the US, which would have to reverse course suddenly and continue climbing to materially change the forecasts for the rest of the year. US is likely to end up with ±26,000 fewer deaths by the end of the year.
While the outcome will be relatively close, the forecast ranges for deaths for the US and the EU do not overlap and are moving apart.

Forecast total US: ~6.5-8M cases with marginally declining CFR over the period, adding 65-85K further deaths to current 687K, total 752-775M
Ballpark EU forecast: plateauing rate then gradual decline/wk overall, adding 35-40K over the period to current 767K, total 802-807K I'm allowing absolute worst case for US as 102K additional deaths, based on surge in cases towards year end, CFR not improving, no booster. Total 789K.
Equally the best realistic case for EU looks like a steady decline in deaths to zero by year end, adding ~27K to current 767K. Total 794K.

The most recent CDC forecast shows U.S. COVID deaths more or less plateauing over about the next four weeks (https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/science/forecasting/forecasting-us.html), but the current U.S. 7-day avg. death rate per million is now around five times that of the E.U. The current reported difference between the two entities has narrowed to about +85,400 E.U. cumulative deaths as of 9/22/21, with just under 100 days until 12/31/21. (https://ourworldindata.org/covid-deaths?country=~USA~EU)

The confirmed-cases-curve in the US has peaked and is on the downslope; the deaths curve will follow, with the usual lag. Thus, the current deaths differential should be expected to resolve with the US still lower in total death count. This has actually been similar (if more severe) than the 2020Q3 pattern, where the US had a big case (and death) run-up that the EU didn't have. The question is, then, will 2021Q4 look like 2020Q4, with a general increase in cases and deaths where the EU number outpaces the US? Or will the EU's higher vaccination rate change the results? And if it does, will it change them enough for the US death total to catch up to the EU's?

I finally was able to make my own spreadsheet of all these countries and their weekly average daily deaths, vaccinations, etc.  I don’t understand the reasoning behind these crowd odds of only 5%. If there is an extreme amount of confidence it should be on the other end.  There are 99 days remaining until 31 December. The European Union’s total deaths exceed those of the United States by something like 92,000. The US is catching up by way more than 1000 per day. With momentums in place I don’t see how it won’t easily surpass the EU. The EU in general has higher vaccination rates, stronger vaccination mandates, and a less-stressed hospital system.

Lots of good analysis already in recent comments. As of 18 Sep, there are 673,472 COVID fatalities in the US and 764,148 in the EU, for a difference of 90,676. What is the likelihood on this day that 90,677 _more_ people will die in the US of COVID than EU by 31 Dec (104 days away from the 18th)? If the US averages 872 deaths _more_ than the EU _per day_, this question will resolve to "Yes."  Currently the US is on a 7-day rolling average of 1,381 more deaths per day than the EU. The US has been over the 872 threshold every day since 30 Aug, or 19 straight days. The death rate in the US has been accelerating continuously and sharply for about 7 weeks while in the EU, the increase in fatalities has been slower and shows signs of tapering. Case growth has flattened at a very high level in the US and is diminishing from a much lower level in the EU. The EU has a higher percentage of people partially and fully vaccinated (the difference between partial and fully vaccinated is so significant in the US I wonder if there are data reporting errors). The EU has more disparity within member states than the US does within states. Without doing any research I attribute it more to supply issues than willingness to take the vaccine, though the states with lower rates (e.g., Bulgaria, Poland) tend to be relatively lower income nations with less educational attainment and state capacity to encourage vaccinations (such as France's controversial but successful system for requiring a digital pass to enter restaurants and other public spaces). Point being, I think despite having a higher overall rate of vaccination, the EU also has more "low hanging fruit" of people who will get the vaccine once it is accessible to them. I predict
* the US will exceed the EU in average daily deaths for the rest of 2021, at least for 90% of days remaining..
* the 3rd wave in the US will plateau and start to decline.
* the Biden mandate for employers of 100 and above to enforce vaccine or negative test checks will either not go into effect at all (court injunction, etc.), or if it does, it will have a minor impact in the vaccination rate in 2021 (e.g., too little impact to incorporate in forecasts).
* in both geographies, deaths will fall until mid-November, at which point they will start increasing again, coinciding with flu season.
* any subsequent waves will hit the US harder than EU because of lower levels of vaccination and lower tolerance for restrictive measures. More specifically:
* On 9 Oct: the US will have recorded 710,000 deaths; EU 775,000 (difference of 65,000)
* On 30 Oct: 730,000 & 778,000 (48,000). As these dates approach I will see how my estimates performed and update accordingly. I currently expect the EU to end up with about 30,000 more cumulative deaths from COVID on 31 Dec.

So, very close via this one rough projection.. ..Will watch the U.S. death totals and rate vs. EU going forward but I'll take a generally optimistic view (for now) that the U.S. can eventually slow its latest 'spike', via more widespread/more stringent controls, mandates.

Long overdue for a review on this one.  As with so many of these COVID questions the situation that 6 weeks ago was running with high degrees of projected certainty has changed (from a certainty perspective if nothing else) and so the objective imperative must be to adjust certainty (noting the underlying pain and discomfort I'm feeling in moving so far from the current crowd position). I have a feeling on this one that the current, fairly static crowd position may be more due to a lack of updated forecasts from the majority rather than a reflection of high to near absolute certainty of a "no" outcome....at least I hope that's what it is (as opposed to having missed something fundamental that everyone else but me has seen)!   Top and tail review of the question's forecast follows.
 ----------- "Yes" Factors to consider (i.e. increasing likelihood): -In the US: the stalling of the vaccine programme as progress hits the hardening divide between the "willing" and the "unwilling".  i.e. the rapid process the US enjoyed at the start of the year may have hit its apogee.
-In the US: the steadily growing volume of anti-vax narratives and tribalism within the echo chambers of the already "unwilling" or the "vaccine sceptical" (likely reinforcing the existing stall rather than correcting it).  i.e. the current trend path is likely to continue over the question period.
-In the US: incoming flu season (a worldwide concern) that whilst not directly attributable to this question (focused as it is on COVID attributed fatalities) will further pressurise the US Healthcare system that is already creaking in specific areas (resulting in a more general increase in mortality rates for all conditions).
-In the US: the current trend path of case and fatality rates (well math'd by @Columbus [1]) that, on current trends, sees the US ending the year with approximately 10,000 more COVID fatalities than the EU (a noteworthy projection with a narrow and fragile margin of error for forecasting)
-In the US: College football season (August to December 21) and its potential to become a major spreader vector [2].
-In the EU: the slow but steady ramping up of vaccine rollout progress [3] and the general vaccine willingness of the EU population vs their US counterparts (more an issue of availability and accessibility in the EU than one of willingness)
-In the EU: the aggregated performance and capacity of "EU healthcare" vs the US equivalents
-In the EU: a return to lockdowns in response to a serious surge in cases & fatalities or a new variant is more likely to be accepted and complied with both politically and socially in Europe than it is in the US (very much my personal perception and recognising that the UK's woeful performance and political environment no longer influences the EU's statics).
-In Both: similarities in political desire (sometimes despite medical advice) to reopen economies and reduce restrictions that seem likely (at this juncture) to see trend lines for both parties continue on their current upward trend paths without significant divergence. "No" Factors to Consider (i.e. reducing likelihood): -In the US: the inherent advantage in agility of response that the US enjoys over their European counterparts (as seen in the difference in speed of vaccine rollout programmes).  Impact on probability reduction questionable at this juncture given that Biden appears to be running out of options that sit within his direct remit and don't require bi-partisan cooperation from congress and at state level (which effectively nullifies this advantage for the US!).
(ADDED)-In the US: New Executive orders that are applying a more directive and mandatory impetus to the vaccine roll out than has been seen to date.  Republicans are highly likely to howl about government overreach, wail about the rise of Communism in America and sue in friendly states in order to test these executive orders in what they hope will be their Trump card (pun intended) majority in the SC.  Never-the-less it is possible that these new measures may encourage the mildly vaccine hesitant (as opposed to the tiny minority of die hard hold outs) to roll their sleeves up as they did in France [4]. 
-In the EU: The EU being ahead of the US in cumulative fatalities by 106,287 [5] with four months of the question left to go
-In the EU:  significant difference in starting population base rate (US: 333 million [6] vs EU: 447 million [7]) ---------------- With all the above hopefully being accurate, true, relevant and applicable (please feedback, comment and challenge) the (heavily revised) conclusions I've come to for this question are: 1.  The current trend path sees the US overtaking the EU by a small but significant margin at question's closure.
2.  Current political and societal behaviours, attitudes and mitigating strategies do not seem likely to fundamentally change the current trend path within this question's timeframe (despite Biden's best efforts). 
3.  That most of the foreseeable change factors (new variants [8], new surges, general winter season illnesses etc.) are likely to affect both parties to this question fairly equally (in terms of impact on current trend path).  Exception to this might be college football season in the US which has significant potential to increase Delta variant spread (and therefore fatality rates and potential for new, more lethal US born variants).
4.  The slim margin of projected difference between EU and US by 31st December 21 makes any forecast more vulnerable to the impact of the above change factors (and therefore less justifiably certain overall). TLDR Version: current data and reporting seems to require a 180 degree shift in projection from "no" to "yes" but with a fairly narrow certainty margin (slim differential at questions close, lots of potential routes to disruption of current trend paths for both sides).   With college football and the entrenched political positions in play in the US at this moment (and their noticeable impact on US COVID management performance) I'm revising up to just under a 2/3rds chance of the US recording higher fatality rates at this time (with some underlying concern that even that may be a little too confident in a "yes" outcome at this moment). The 7-day rolling average of COVID-19 deaths has kept on going down for for both the US and EU, and the EU has just managed to slip to having fewer/day (192) than the US (219). However, even if the EU went down to zero, the US death rate would have to more than treble from the current level for its death total to catch up by the end of the year.  And, well, the EU is still lower on percentage of population vaccinated, lower on percentage of population fully vaccinated, and has higher total population, meaning they've currently got more people vulnerable to a new wave on both a percentage basis and a raw numbers basis.

On the seven-day rolling average of deaths/day, the EU deaths/day are 345, versus the US's 249, which is to say, the EU is still building on its lead in deaths. Given they're already 134,778 deaths higher than the US as of July 1st, the EU would need the US to average more than 736 more deaths/day than the EU for the rest of the year for the US to catch up. So if the EU managed to cut its deaths to zero at the same time the US had its deaths treble, then the US could just barely edge the EU in death total. On vaccinations, the US is 54% vaccinated to the EU's 51%, and 47% fully-vaccinated to the EU's 34%. So in the short run, at least, the EU is much more vulnerable than the US to renewed breakouts. The US has also had more confirmed cases, and thus a much higher percentage of the population having had confirmed cases. If that reflects an actual underlying higher case rate, that means more of the US population is not vulnerable going forward, having already gained natural immunity. (if it just reflects a higher test rate, well, then it means nothing.)

The EU currently has 133,958 more attributed deaths than the US. In order for the US total to exceed the European, the US will need to average 679.99 more deaths/day for the rest of the year than the EU. The current seven-day rolling average of daily deaths in the EU is 464.43 deaths/day, the same for the US is 334.14 deaths/day. So, if the EU dropped to zero deaths/day tomorrow and held there for the rest of the year, while the US averaged twice its current deaths/day for the rest of the year, the EU would STILL have the higher total at the end of the year. Fundamentally, the only way the US could exceed the EU is if there were a major case spike that affected the US much more severely than the EU, overcoming the facts that the US population is smaller AND at present is substantially more fully-vaccinated (43.97% versus 25.90%). I'm not going to say "absolutely impossible", but I'm confident in a 0% prediction being closer than 1%.

EU currently has a slighter higher death tally (~449K per https://www.ecdc.europa.eu/en/cases-2019-ncov-eueea, cao 28 Jan) than the US (~438K per WHO data, cao 2 Feb). However, there is reason to believe that the EU will see a greater toll in 2021.  First, underlying demographic factors will play a role.  EU population (~447.5M) and population density (112 ppl/sq. km) are both higher than in the US (~328.2M & 36 ppl/sq. km) (data.WorldBank.org). Also, the EU population is older than the US population, providing a larger proportion and total number of people over age 65 that are susceptible to severe cases of COVID (EU - 20.3% vs. US - 15.2%). Additionally, the initial vaccine rollout int he US (7.1 doses administered per 100 ppl) has been more successful than in the EU (2.3 doses administered per 100 ppl), suggesting that vaccination will provide adequate levels of herd immunity in the US faster than in the EU.  Additionally, more contagious strains of the virus seem more widespread in the EU at this point, although that will most likely soon even out in the US as the spread strains take hold in North America. Things that might change my estimate: More strict lockdowns in the EU and lessening of lockdowns or distancing policies in the US.  Comparatively accelerated vaccine rollout in the EU, or disruptions in US vaccination program.  Significant comparative differences in vaccine hesitancy rates.

Coming in low as a start point given that the US is coming into 2021 under the EU's fatality total by approximately 30,000* and the vaccine programmes for both suggest a diverging trend line over the question period. Given the likely difference in speed, effectiveness and raw buying power of the two Federal governments in their attempts to control the virus and rollout a vaccine programme I currently assess the US to have a significant edge on 2021's case and death rates.  Whilst the US certainly has its own political and social problems with stricter virus control measures (and will likely continue to have in certain pockets) this is likely to be mirrored by "lockdown fatigue" and increasing political & economic pressures across the EU. In the US the areas with less control measure compliance / greater control measure resistance seem to be the more rural, sparsely populated areas, whereas the opposite is true in several EU countries. The EU also appears to have a greater variance in healthcare quality provision across all its 27 member states than the US (although, for fairly obvious reasons, the US could be said to have a generally lower standard of healthcare per capita in comparison to specific EU nations [2 & 3]). The EU as a whole seems to have a greater generalised exposure to new and emergent virus variants given the collective difficulty in keeping them out and proactively controlling them once inside the free movement area.  The US has an inherently greater and more agile capability to respond effectively to new and emergent conditions, and with the renewed competency in government it can be expected to see this come into play more often. The EU also has less flexibility and "emergency executive authority" to "gracefully extend" [4] into the emergency's management and share healthcare resources ("reciprocity" in David Wood's language) across borders. As such conditions seem to forecast a faster falling death rate in the US now that competency, compassion and conviction has returned to its executive leadership.  The EU will continue to do its best but, so far, has shown little willingness to push the boundaries of its political, structural and constitutional systems to gain the kind of flexibility, agility and momentum that the US is working towards. To be reviewed with live figures as the year progresses, conditions change and their impacts are measured. *Using "ourworldindata" [1] for this as it seems to be an easier resource to work with than the WHO webpage, but I'm working on the assumption that the OWID team have already removed the UK from the EU's data (the UK officially left the EU in January 2020 although some places still consider the UK part of "Europe").  Had they now I believe the EU's fatality rate would have been skewed much harder upwards. I think the European Union is in for a much worse 2021 than the US. I'm very optimistic on vaccinations in the US. The US has purchased enough vaccinations to cover the entire population twice over, and is on track to have every adult who wants a vaccination vaccinated by summer. The EU also has enough to cover twice its population, but my understanding is many of these purchases came later, so the US likely has priority. Big factors in the question aside from speed:
1.) Vaccine acceptance: Surprisingly US is actually favored on this one. Polls I've seen show several EU countries with abysmal vaccine acceptance.
2.) Anti-covid efforts: I'd guess the US loses on this one. Among the people who won't get vaccinated here are likely a lot of people who also refuse to wear masks and take basic steps to suppress the virus. 3.) Medical prevention: I think this is probably about even, I think both countries will get better at keeping COVID patients alive at about the same rate.
4.) Starting point: Cumulative deaths and daily deaths are at about the same place for both countries, so starting on pretty equal footing.  Overall I see US as having quite a better shot at preventing deaths than the EU.

I would expect the EU to have more deaths attributable to Covid-19 on Dec. 31, 2021 for the following reasons. The EU has a larger and slightly older (therefore more vulnerable) population than the United States, and is currently leading the United States in deaths. The EU also has a lower vaccination rate. If rates of infection, vaccination, and death remain somewhat constant, it is reasonable to assume the EU would have more COVID-19 deaths at the end of 2021. While both the EU and the US will likely see vaccination rates increase as the vaccine supply expands and distribution becomes more efficient, I think it is unlikely that the EU's vaccination rate will significantly outpace that of the US. The EU will likely face some distribution challenges that the US will not, as vaccines need to be allocated and distributed across national borders. Variables that could increase the likelihood of the United States having more Covid-19 deaths at the end of 2021 include: (1) the possibility that the EU has already seen a significant increase in the spread of contagious strains that the US has yet to see (resulting in more infections and an increase in deaths), (2) increased or improved reporting of deaths in the US as the new administration makes a push to take Covid-19 more seriously, and (3) the possibility of significant resistance to vaccination in the US due to politicization of the virus at a level not seen in the EU.

This is a question about how many deaths will be reported, not how many occur. Points that other people have made about the relative population and relative death rates of the United States versus the European Union are important to this question, but not as important as how likely the United States and European Union are to change their testing methodology. Florida and Colorado are already making their testing centers report their cycle thresholds, and this is why Florida is able to report so few cases when they are fully open with full tourism and even Disney world open, and with one of the oldest populations in the country. California, however, has one of the youngest populations in the country and is much more strictly locked down, yet has a much higher covid rate right now because they are testing without regard to what the cycle thresholds of the test centers are, which means they have a much higher rate of false positives.  I think it is telling that as of the day of the Biden inauguration the mass media reporting on covid instantly changed to one of turning the corner covid and a message of hope rather than doom. I think there will be continued pressure at multiple levels of government to show that we are coming to grips with the virus. I think more States will also begin to look more seriously at the cycle thresholds of their PCR testing. I think the European Union will be slower to react to the PCR testing issue as their healthcare system is more bureaucratic and top-down.
